Uploaded patch set 11: Commit message was updated.

Patch Set 11:

(2 comments)

Patch Set 11:

Patch Set 11:

(1 comment)

Abandoned

Merged as part of another series.
This patchset is definitely coming along!

Rather than making this a template, can we just explicitly call out the 6 types we need?

uint64_t, int64_t, string, and pointer/optional equivalents, right?

That's going to prevent int16_t* from getting a different template expansion than int64_t*, which could be using the same code.
Sure I can do that.
Ack

this helper has been proposed before.  The problem for me as a maintainer is that people use it blindly, and completely ignore the schema requirements for optionality and error codes.  As is, even when they're writing the code by hand, they still ignore the requiredness of parameters.  If a Redfish-schema required parameter isn't present, the request should 500.  Helper functions like this don't account for that.  I could maybe see it if there were also a counterpart like "assignIfOrError" so it explicitly made users select which one they had to use, and we had a common way for handling with error, and without error, but as written, I don't think this gets us there.

For example, I'm pretty sure the std::is_pointer_v should be setting internal error, right?

This helper should be used together with unpackPropertiesNoThrow.
unpackPropertiesNoThrow have some guarantees. If there is no error all pointers are set and valid. Optional can be empty, if optional<const T*> is filled it contains valid pointer.

My point still stands, regardless of the last sentence, as-written, this doesn't handle errors and isn't capable of returning 500 on bad parameters.  It looks like you fixed that in your latest patch.
Yes, this change was removed from latest patchset.

nullptr dereference.  Pointer types aren't guaranteed to be filled.  FWIW, in my first reading of this, this template code is complex enough that I didn't catch that.  We need to refactor similar to the previous comment to make it more obvious when this is done wrong.

If used together with unpackPropertiesNoThrow pointers are guaranteed to be filled. I guess using this function can be confusing in case of pointers. I can split it and name it 'assign' to indicate that pointer needs to be valid.

> If used together with unpackPropertiesNoThrow pointers are guaranteed to be filled.

The key word being "If".  Pointer safety should be guaranteed, and verifiable at the call site, not just if they're used the way the author intended.

> I guess using this function can be confusing in case of pointers. I can split it and name it 'assign' to indicate that pointer needs to be valid.
I changed how unpackPropertiesNoThrow behaves. Now every pointer needs to be checked before using.
ACK

This is an example of the error I talked about above.  CertificateString is required in the Certificate interface, so if we don't get it, it should be an error.  Admittedly, we handle that poorly in the lefthand side code by just setting it to empty string, which passes the validator but is arguably wrong, but still more correct than this new code.

I just changed it to have same behavior. If this field is required then in line 596 it should be changed from optional<const std::string*> to const std::string* then it is guaranteed that if unpackPropertiesNoThrow doesn't return error pointer is set.
Ack
Possible nullptr dereference.  Per the rules, we need to be checking pointers for validity in the scope in which they're dereferenced.
It is guaranteed by unpackPropertiesNoThrow that it wont return nullptr in optional if no error is returned.
This is obsolete. In new version of unpackPropertiesNoThrow you need to check pointer before dereferencing.
Nit, and not a problem with your patch, but this function doesn't need to take ownership of the Response, so it shouldn't be passed by shared_ptr, but by Response&
I will fix it.
Ack

I'd really rather this function do less, it looks like it's doing double duty for both setting a key, and converting kb to MB.

Also, isn't this technically bytes to MB?

I just assumed that if dbus property is named AllocationIncrementInKiB and redfish schema is AllocationIncrementMiB.

I googled 'convert 1024 kib to mib' it seems to be correct unless I'm mistaking something.
Ack
This is the same issue as the first nit.  This function doesn't take ownership, so we shouldn't be passing by shared_ptr.  use Response& directly.
Ack
Looks like this patch got mixed up with a some other refactoring and cleanup?
I can revert it back to how it was. I did this because this was small change that helped with this patch set (I needed to write less code).
Ack
Generally we avoid declaring multiple variables of the same type on the same line, as it makes this code a lot harder to read.
I will fix it in final version.
Ack
Do we need to be printing more specifics here of which property failed to be read out?

It's something that you suggested. To return index instead of std::string to decrease binary size. If you have suggestion how to print property name instead of index of property that failed without impact on binary size I can do that,
printing is only enabled when logging is enabled, so the impact on binary size for logging is negligible so long as the compiler can delete the code when logging is disabled.
Okay. I will do as suggested.

I double checked it, compiler is not able to fully optimize 'error' variable which is returned from sdbusplus. Not matter if it's printed or not as long as we use to determine if error occurred it won't be optimized. So if index is used we can save some binary size. If we return std::string with name of property it will improve debug messages but we will have to pay for even if logs are dissabled.

FWIW, we hit this problem the last time we tried to implement a templatized unpack for property unpacking.  Given the amount of time we spend debugging minor property type problems (string type instead of object_path, uint32 instead of uint64), it would be really hard to lose this level of inspectability and logging.

I wonder if there's a path to where you could pass in a "on_error" callback to the unpack call?  That way, when logging is disabled, on_error would optimize down to nothing, and if logging is enabled, we would get the behavior we want.

Just thinking out loud.
Detailed debug information is now available and callback helped with decreasing binary size. Check updated commit message for details.
Looks like you didn't intend to add this?
Yes, I don't know how this happened.
Ack

Some quick back of the napkin math.  There are 40 calls to GetAll in bmcweb.  This commit ports 2 of them to the new pattern, and adds 1kB while doing it.  Assuming that pattern holds, moving all of them would result in a 20KB increase in bmcweb size, or about a 2% increase in the total size.  We need to decide if that's worth it, or if we expect the scaling to net us some wins as we roll this out other places.
I will change few more calls to GetAll it should help with making decision.

Thanks.  I don't mean to be a stickler for this, but considering my last 12 patches have been trying to optimize the binary size to get bmcweb back to within its listed requirements, I'd really like to not move backwards.
Latest patchset looks like it actually drops the binary size.  Good work.
I marked old comments as resolved to clean it up.
ACKJ
This seems more suited for dbus utils?  and ideally would be printing more about the actual error.
I will remove this change from this patchset if you are okay with it.
Ack

I did a quick skim (didn't review the whole thing because it doesn't build).  This is starting to come together.  For the amount of effort, I do really wish it was a more net negative in total lines of code (only -200 with 2000 lines changed) but considering that this gives more consistency, I do think it's a good thing overall

Is this still being worked?  I know the sdbusplus patches merged, but this has been idle for a bit.  Next step should be to get it rebased (see discord for a set of commands to make the clang-format changes automatically), and it should be pretty close to ready.
Both of these are internal Errors.  If we fail to unpack something, there's nothing a user can do about it.
